awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Quantum Software for Scientific and Engineering Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields. 

This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal focused on software development for the implementation of quantum algorithms on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We created a new interdisciplinary undergraduate Quantum Information course, which was taught by the PI in Spring 2020. This was the first course of its kind offered at the University of Tennessee. It was developed in collaboration with industry (Microsoft and IBM Quantum) who provided access to their systems (software and hardware). It was a very successful attempt, as over 30 undergraduate students enrolled from diverse Departments in the College of Arts and Sciences and the Tickle College of Engineering (Physics & Astronomy, Mathematics, Chemistry, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, etc.).

We created a new interdisciplinary graduate course in Quantum Information taught jointly by the PI and Dr. Arun Padakandla of the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. An unprecedented number of graduate students from various Departments enrolled (about 30 graduate students from Physics & Astronomy, Mathematics, Chemistry, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, etc.).

We began a weekly Quantum Information Seminar Series in Spring 2020 which was well attended by students (both undergraduate and graduate) and faculty from various Departments. Speakers hailed from national labs, industry and academia, and included speakers from IonQ, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, MITRE, Google, Honeywell, Volkswagen, IBM, Emory University, Goldman Sachs, D-Wave, and University of Maryland. Unfortunately, the seminars had to be scaled down due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Nevertheless, the interest of students was not diminished.

We assembled a multi-disciplinary research team spanning several institutions led by the PI that developed a concept and a proposal for a Quantum Leap Challenge Institute (QLCI). We proposed to establish the Quantum Fields Institute (QFI), a unique and comprehensive hub centered in the Southeast US for research innovation, education, workforce training, and community/infrastructure development in quantum engineering based on measurement and control of quantum fields, a.k.a. qumodes. Led by the University of Tennessee, the QFI team also included researchers from Stanford University, University of Virginia, University of Arizona, University of Georgia, Florida A&M University, College of William & Mary, Emory University, and Louisiana State University. We obtained support from industry (Xanadu, Microsoft, IBM, Google, GE, General Dynamics, ColdQuanta, Freedom Photonics, Ligentec, Northrop Grumman, Qubitekk, DWave, Raytheon, MITRE, Goldman Sachs, Volkswagen) and national / government laboratories (ORNL, NIST, ARL, JLab, JILA). We also partnered with other universities in the Southeast for workforce development (Fayetteville State University, Fisk University, LeMoyne-Owen College, Tennessee Tech, Tennessee State University, Thomas Nelson College, Norfolk State University).

This award acted as a catalyst for a flurry of activities at the University of Tennessee, including QIS related publications, new collaborations, grants, graduate students and postdocs.

Several new publications in QIS appeared in peer-reviewed Journals authored by the PI and co-PIs Johnston and Ostrowski.

A new collaboration in quantum optimization by the PI and co-PI Ostrowski, together with collaborators at ORNL (Dr. Travis Humble and Dr. Sarah Powers) attracted funding by DARPA and has resulted in publications, training of graduate students and a postdoc.

A new collaboration in quantum topological data analysis by the PI and Dr. Vasileios Maroulas of the Department of Mathematics has received NSF funding and is training a graduate student.

A postdoc in the Department of Physics and Astronomy has been involved part-time in the activities of the team. Several graduate students have joined QIS groups for their PhD thesis or have expressed interest in doing so. This award has acted as a catalyst for a stronger collaboration with the QIS groups at ORNL with joined training of graduate students that resulted in a DOE award for the development of quantum internet.

This award has resulted in increased interest and investment by the administration of the University of Tennessee in QIS. The PI was appointed Director of Quantum Leap Initiative at the Department of
Physics and Astronomy. Several graduate students are expected to be trained in QIS. Ongoing discussions with the University of Tennessee for investment in experimental QIS by infrastructure upgrading of the PI’s quantum optics laboratory which is run in collaboration with researchers holding joint UT/ORNL appointments. The University of Tennessee invested $100K in the quantum optics laboratory of the PI.

The team has been discussing collaboration with other institutions of higher education, including HBCUs, to develop proposals to NSF in programs such as NRT and IUSE for interdisciplinary curriculum development. The team ended up collaborating with the University of Georgia (PI: Yohannes Abate) and developed an NRT proposal titled "Quantum Networks Training and Research Alliance in the Southeast (QuaNTRASE)" for interdisciplinary research focusing on quantum networks, an emerging technology that
harnesses quantum phenomena like entanglement and superposition to encode and process information in ways not possible with current (classical) communication technologies.
